pin_cites.parenthetical: "A mortgage is in essence a defeasible deed, requiring the grantee to reconvey the property held as security to the grantor upon satisfaction of the underlying debt or fulfillment of established conditions."
emphasis added
"[A] mortgage is both in law and in equity only a security for the payment of money and passes no title to the land. The mortgagor is the owner of the land."
"[A] mortgage is both in law and in equity only a security for the payment of money and passes no title to the land. The mortgagor is the owner of the land."
"[I]n Pennsylvania ... a mortgage is only a Ken or incumbrance on the land mortgaged, and that the mortgagee has no estate in the land."
"[I]n Pennsylvania ... a mortgage is only a Ken or incumbrance on the land mortgaged, and that the mortgagee has no estate in the land."
"[I]n Pennsylvania ... a mortgage is only a Ken or incumbrance on the land mortgaged, and that the mortgagee has no estate in the land."

"Though in form a conveyance, [a mortgage] was both at law and equity a mere security for the debt. That such is the nature of a mortgage in Pennsylvania has been frequently ruled by her highest court."
